messages.user_message: What is the appropriate nozzle temperature for 3D printing using fused deposition modeling with polylactic acid (PLA)?
messages.assistant_response: The appropriate nozzle temperature for 3D printing using fused deposition modeling with polylactic acid (PLA) typically ranges from 190째C to 230째C. However, the best properties for pure PLA prints were found at a temperature of 215째C. It is important to note that the optimum printing temperature can be affected by factors such as bed temperature, surrounding temperature, printing speed, and the plastic's crystallinity and thermal properties. Additionally, increasing the nozzle temperature to 240째C can make PLA 3D-printed parts more durable, but temperatures above this can lead to polymer degradation [reference_188.pdf, page 784; reference_120.pdf, page 290].

messages.user_message: What is the appropriate printing speed for 3D printing using fused deposition modeling with polylactic acid (PLA)?
messages.assistant_response: The appropriate printing speed for 3D printing using fused deposition modeling with polylactic acid (PLA) is generally around 90 mm/s. This speed was found to give the highest Young's modulus for pure PLA, indicating optimal mechanical properties. However, the strength of samples tends to decrease with increasing speed, and above 80 mm/s, it decreases significantly. Therefore, while 90 mm/s is optimal for mechanical properties, maintaining a speed below 80 mm/s might be beneficial for strength [reference_120.pdf, page 284; reference_130.pdf, page 1].

messages.user_message: What is the appropriate layer height for 3D printing using fused deposition modeling with polylactic acid (PLA)?
messages.assistant_response: The appropriate layer height for 3D printing using fused deposition modeling with polylactic acid (PLA) can vary depending on the desired surface quality and printing time. In a study, the layer height was varied from 0.05 mm to 0.25 mm. It was found that a smaller layer height, such as 0.05 mm, resulted in smoother surface finishes, while a larger layer height, like 0.25 mm, led to rougher surfaces. Additionally, the printing time is inversely proportional to the surface roughness, meaning that smaller layer heights will generally increase printing time [reference_145.pdf, page 2].
